SENT.plain: The pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is only partially understood
Various environmental and host (e.g. genetic-, epithelial-, immune and non-immune) factors are involved
It is a multifactorial polygenic disease with probable genetic heterogeneity
Some genes are associated with IBD itself, while others increase the risk of ulcerative colitis (UC) or Crohn's disease (CD) or are associated with disease location and/or behaviour
This review addresses recent advances in the genetics of IBD
The article discusses the current information on the crosstalk between microbial and genetic factors (e.g. NOD2/CARD15, SLC22A46A5 and DLG5)
The genetic data acquired in recent years help in understanding the pathogenesis of IBD and can identify a number of potential targets for therapeutic intervention
In the future, genetics may help more accurately diagnose and predict disease course in IBD
